passages.title: The Miser and His Gold
passages.passage: Once there was a miser who sold all his possessions and, with the money, bought a great lump of gold, dug a deep hole at the edge of the garden, and there he buried his gold. Once a day, thereafter, the miser went to the garden, dug up his gold, and embraced it lovingly. One of the miser's workmen wondered why his master spent so much time in the garden. One day, he hid behind a tree and soon discovered the secret of the hidden treasure. That night, when the miser was fast asleep, the workman crept into the garden and stole the lump of gold. When the miser found that his gold was gone, he tore his hair and cried aloud in his despair. A neighbour came running to see what the matter was, and the grief-stricken miser told him what had happened. Then the neighbour said, "Pray stop your weeping. Go and find a stone. Place the stone in the hole and imagine that it is your lump of gold. The stone will serve your purpose, for you never meant to use the gold anyway. It makes little difference whether it is gold or stone if you are never going to use it."

questions.question: How did the miser get the lump of gold?
questions.answer: By selling all he had
questions.explanation: The passage states that the miser 'sold all his possessions and, with the money, bought a great lump of gold'.

questions.question: Why did the miser spend so much time in the garden?
options: He liked watching children playing in the garden
To keep an eye on his hidden treasure
To change the place of his lump of gold
questions.answer: To keep an eye on his hidden treasure
questions.explanation: The passage says 'Once a day, thereafter, the miser went to the garden, dug up his gold, and embraced it lovingly.'

questions.question: By whom was the gold stolen?
questions.answer: The miser's workman
questions.explanation: The passage clearly states 'the workman crept into the garden and stole the lump of gold'.

questions.question: The neighbour told the miser to...
questions.answer: stop crying
questions.explanation: The neighbour said, 'Pray stop your weeping. Go and find a stone.'

questions.question: The neighbour advised the miser to put a stone in the hole because...
options: Gold is like a stone only
The miser would never use the gold, hence there was no difference between the two
The stone will become gold after some time
For a wise man, gold and stone has equal worth
questions.answer: The miser would never use the gold, hence there was no difference between the two
questions.explanation: The neighbour said 'The stone will serve your purpose, for you never meant to use the gold anyway. It makes little difference whether it is gold or stone if you are never going to use it.'

questions.question: What did the miser do with the gold?
questions.answer: The miser dug a deep hole at the edge of the garden and buried his gold there. Once a day, he would dig it up and embrace it lovingly.

questions.question: How often did the miser go to the garden? What did he do there?
questions.answer: The miser went to the garden once a day. He would dig up his gold and embrace it lovingly.

questions.question: What did the workman do one day and how did the miser react to the loss?
questions.answer: One night, the workman crept into the garden and stole the lump of gold. When the miser found that his gold was gone, he tore his hair and cried aloud in his despair.

questions.question: What advice did the neighbour give the miser?
questions.answer: The neighbour advised the miser to stop weeping, find a stone, place it in the hole, and imagine it was his lump of gold. He said the stone would serve the same purpose since the miser never intended to use the gold anyway.

questions.question: Find the word in the passage that means: A person who loves to have money but hates to spend it.
questions.answer: Miser

questions.question: Find the word in the passage that means: A state of having lost all hope.
questions.answer: Despair

passages.title: The Train Journey
passages.passage:
I entered the second class compartment and took a corner seat. A few minutes later, a large, noisy family rushed in and spread themselves all over the compartment. The parents arranged and rearranged their belongings on the luggage racks. A suitcase fell on the grandmother's feet and she shouted at them. The children quarrelled and the baby cried.

Suddenly, the whistle blew and with much clanging and groaning the train moved out of the station. It soon gathered speed and rushed on through the night.

My companions opened large tiffin carriers and settled down to their meal. But the baby's cries became howls and the grandmother hung a saree from the chain on the side wall of the carriage. She put the baby in this cradle and the baby stopped crying almost at once.

At the same time, the train came to a halt. There was a great commotion. I looked out of the window and found that a large crowd had gathered outside and everyone was asking who had pulled the chain. Suddenly I saw that the grandmother had hung the cradle on the alarm chain!

questions.question: Who were the occupants of the second class compartment?
questions.answer: The occupants were the narrator, and a large, noisy family consisting of parents, children, a baby, and a grandmother.

questions.question: Why did the grandmother shout?
questions.answer: The grandmother shouted because a suitcase fell on her feet while the parents were arranging their belongings on the luggage racks.

questions.question: How did the grandmother make a cradle?
questions.answer: The grandmother hung a saree from the chain on the side wall of the carriage to make a cradle for the baby.

questions.question: Why did the train stop?
questions.answer: The train stopped because the grandmother had accidentally hung the cradle on the alarm chain, which pulled the chain and caused the train to halt.

questions.question: What two things stopped almost at the same time?
questions.answer: The baby's crying and the train both stopped almost at the same time - the baby stopped crying when put in the cradle, and the train stopped because the alarm chain was pulled.

questions.question: The family that entered the compartment was...
questions.answer: large and noisy

questions.question: A great noise was created inside the compartment by...
questions.answer: the children quarrelling and the baby crying

questions.question: Soon after the train gathered speed, the family...
questions.answer: opened large tiffin carriers and settled down to their meal

questions.question: As soon as the baby was put in the cradle...
questions.answer: the baby stopped crying almost at once

questions.question: The grandmother had hung the cradle...
questions.answer: on the alarm chain

questions.question: Find the word in the passage that means: had a heated argument or disagreement.
questions.answer: Quarrelled

questions.question: Find the word in the passage that means: open out something.
questions.answer: Spread

questions.question: Find the word in the passage that means: a series of linked metals.
questions.answer: Chain

questions.question: Find the word in the passage that means: come together; assemble.
questions.answer: Gathered

questions.question: Find the word in the passage that means: a lot of noise and confusion.
questions.answer: Commotion

passages.title: Homesickness by Roald Dahl
passages.passage:
I was homesick during the whole of my first term at St Peter's. Homesickness is a bit like seasickness. You don't know how awful it is till you get it, and when you do, it hits you right in the top of the stomach and you want to die. The only comfort is that both homesickness and seasickness are instantly curable. The first goes away the moment you walk out of the school grounds and the second is forgotten as soon as the ship enters port.

I was so terribly homesick during my first two weeks that I set about making a plan for getting myself sent back home, even if it were for only a few days. My idea was that I should all of a sudden develop an attack of acute appendicitis.

You will probably think it silly that a nine-year old boy imagined that he could get away with a trick like that, but I had sound reasons for trying it. Only a month before, my elder sister had actually had appendicitis, and for several days before her operation I was able to observe her behavior at close quarters. I noticed that the thing she complained about the most was a severe pain down in the lower right side of her tummy. As well as this, she kept being sick and refused to eat and ran a temperature.

You might, by the way, be interested that this sister had her appendix removed not in a fine hospital operating-room full of bright lights and gowned nurses, but on our own nursery table at home by the local doctor and his anesthetist. In those days it was fairly common practice for a doctor to arrive at your house with a bag of instruments, then drape a clean sheet over the most convenient table and get on with it.

On this occasion, I can remember lurking in the corridor outside the nursery while the operation was going on. My other sisters were with me, and we stood spellbound, listening to the soft medical murmurs coming from behind the locked door.

The next day we were allowed to inspect the appendix itself in a glass bottle. It was a longish black wormy-looking thing, and I said, "Do I have one of those inside me, Nanny?"
"Everybody has one," Nanny answered.
"What's it for?" I asked her.
"God works in mysterious ways," she said, which was her stock reply whenever she did not know the answer.
"What makes it go bad?" I asked her.
"Toothbrush bristles," she answered, this time with no hesitation at all. "Whenever a bristle comes out of your toothbrush and you swallow it, it sticks to your appendix and turns it rotten," she added.

As I went upstairs and knocked on the brown door after breakfast, I did not even feel frightened of the Matron.
"Come in!" boomed the voice. I entered the room clutching my stomach on the right-hand side and staggered pathetically.
"What's the matter with you?" the Matron shouted. "It hurts, Matron," I moaned. "Oh, it hurts so much! Just here!"

questions.question: What is St Peter's?
questions.answer: A school
questions.explanation: The passage mentions 'my first term at St Peter's' and 'the moment you walk out of the school grounds', indicating St Peter's is a school.

questions.question: Seasickness occurs when...
questions.answer: Travelling by ship
questions.explanation: The passage says seasickness 'is forgotten as soon as the ship enters port', implying it occurs while travelling by ship.

questions.question: The expression 'at close quarters' means...
questions.answer: To observe closely
questions.explanation: In context, the writer says he was able to 'observe her behavior at close quarters', meaning he could watch her closely.

questions.question: Appendicitis causes pain in the...
options: Lower right side of the stomach
questions.answer: Lower right side of the stomach
questions.explanation: The passage states 'a severe pain down in the lower right side of her tummy'.

questions.question: The writer's sister had the operation in...
questions.answer: The nursery at home
questions.explanation: The passage says 'this sister had her appendix removed... on our own nursery table at home'.

questions.question: What did the children inspect after the operation?
questions.answer: The appendix
questions.explanation: The passage states 'we were allowed to inspect the appendix itself in a glass bottle'.

questions.question: The word 'lurking' means...
questions.answer: Waiting quietly
questions.explanation: In context, 'lurking in the corridor' means waiting quietly and secretly outside the room.

questions.question: The word 'spellbound' means...
questions.answer: To be fascinated
questions.explanation: The children 'stood spellbound, listening to the soft medical murmurs' - they were fascinated and completely absorbed.

questions.question: According to the nanny, what causes the appendix to turn rotten?
questions.answer: Swallowing toothbrush bristles
questions.explanation: The nanny said 'Whenever a bristle comes out of your toothbrush and you swallow it, it sticks to your appendix and turns it rotten'.

questions.question: The term 'to stagger' means...
questions.answer: To walk with difficulty
questions.explanation: The writer 'staggered pathetically' while pretending to be in pain, meaning he walked unsteadily.

questions.question: How does the writer think homesickness can be cured?
questions.answer: The writer thinks homesickness can be cured instantly by walking out of the school grounds - the moment you leave school, the homesickness goes away.

questions.question: What symptoms did the writer's sister show for appendicitis?
questions.answer: The writer's sister complained about severe pain in the lower right side of her tummy. She also kept being sick, refused to eat, and ran a temperature.

questions.question: What did the other children do while the operation was going on?
questions.answer: The other children stood with the writer in the corridor outside the nursery, lurking and spellbound, listening to the soft medical murmurs coming from behind the locked door.

questions.question: How does the writer describe the appendix?
questions.answer: The writer describes the appendix as 'a longish black wormy-looking thing' that he saw in a glass bottle.

questions.question: Why did the writer go to see the Matron?
questions.answer: The writer went to see the Matron to fake appendicitis symptoms. He entered clutching his stomach on the right-hand side and staggered pathetically, moaning that it hurt, hoping to be sent home.

passages.title: Environmental Pollution
passages.passage:
The introduction of harmful waste materials that are hazardous to life, the natural world and our activities, is commonly known as pollution. Pollution has harmful effects on the ecosystem. It disturbs the balance of the biosphere in which living beings survive. This imbalance of oxygen, nitrogen, carbon dioxide, argon and water vapour causes discomfort to all living organisms on the planet. It depletes the ozone layer over the earth that defends us from the damaging ultraviolet rays of the sun. The major types of environmental pollution are air pollution, water pollution, noise pollution, thermal pollution, soil pollution and light pollution. Environmental pollution is caused by deforestation and hazardous gaseous emissions.

Air pollution is caused by the smoke emitted by cars, buses, trucks, trains and factories. This is known to cause lung cancer, asthma, allergies, and various skin and breathing problems along with severe and irreparable damage to flora and fauna. Water pollution is caused when industrial waste products are released into lakes, rivers, and other water bodies. This is destructive for the marine ecosystem. Noise pollution is caused by loud noises from aircrafts, cars, buses and trucks, vehicle horns, loudspeakers and noise from factories.

Soil pollution is a result of acid rain, polluted water, fertilizers, etc. In short, this occurs when chemicals are released into the soil. Light pollution includes use of excess lighting equipment. The excessive and inappropriate use of artificial light causes several phenomena that decrease visibility and cause severe visual discomfort. Light pollution is a great hindrance to astronomy as it has become increasingly difficult to view the night sky because of interference from artificial light. The last decade has witnessed an alarming rise in environmental pollution. This problem is even more alarming as this has caused irreparable damage to the earth.

questions.question: What is pollution?
questions.answer: Pollution is the introduction of harmful waste materials that are hazardous to life, the natural world and our activities.

questions.question: Mention four different kinds of pollution.
questions.answer: The four different kinds of pollution are: (1) Air pollution, (2) Water pollution, (3) Noise pollution, and (4) Soil pollution. (Light pollution and thermal pollution are also mentioned in the passage.)

questions.question: What are the two chief causes of environmental pollution?
questions.answer: The two chief causes of environmental pollution are deforestation and hazardous gaseous emissions.

questions.question: What is causing the waters to get polluted?
questions.answer: Water pollution is caused when industrial waste products are released into lakes, rivers, and other water bodies.

questions.question: Mention any two causes of noise pollution.
questions.answer: Two causes of noise pollution are: (1) Loud noises from aircrafts, cars, buses and trucks, and (2) Vehicle horns and loudspeakers.

questions.question: What is the most disturbing consequence of increasing pollution?
questions.answer: The most disturbing consequence of increasing pollution is that it has caused irreparable damage to the earth. It disturbs the balance of the biosphere and depletes the ozone layer that protects us from ultraviolet rays.

questions.question: The word 'hazardous' means...
questions.answer: Dangerous
questions.explanation: Hazardous means dangerous or risky, as the passage talks about 'harmful waste materials that are hazardous to life'.

questions.question: The word 'irreparable' means...
questions.answer: Beyond repair
questions.explanation: Irreparable means something that cannot be repaired or fixed, as in 'irreparable damage'.

questions.question: The word 'alarming' means...
questions.answer: Frightening
questions.explanation: Alarming means causing worry or fear, as in 'an alarming rise in environmental pollution'.
